statement.p: Think of a number. Add four to your number. Now double that. Then add six. Then halve it. Finally, subtract 7. What is the result? Do you always get the same result, regardless of what number you start with? How does this work? Explain using algebra.

solution.p: Let's start with the number x and follow the instructions: x
Add four to the number: x + 4
Now double that: 2(x+4)
Then add six: 2(x+4)+6
Then halve it: \frac{2(x + 4)+ 6}{2}
Finally, subtract 7: \frac{2(x + 4)+ 6}{2}-7
This expression can be simplified: \frac{2(x + 4)+ 6}{2}-7 \amp = \frac{2x+8+6}{2} - 7 \amp = \frac{2x+14}{2}-7 \amp = x + 7 - 7 \amp = x
Thus, after following the instructions, you always end up with the original number.
